title: Did the eastern part of the Roman Empire become the Byzantine Empire? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes and no The eastern part was renamed as Roman Empire when the western part fell, and this name( or close permutstions as Roman Kingdom or Kingdom of Romans) was the legal name of the eastern part till the end. And after the end. In the end of the 16th century, the Germans who have styled themselves as the “Holy Roman Empire of the German nation” wanted to steal the “Roman-ness” from the actual descendants of the Roman empire. They pushed for renaming the defunct empire and call it Byzantine. That's it. It is like if the USA stops existing then Brazil renames itself as “the Holy USA of the Brazilian nation” and then pushes for the name Washingtonia for the USA.

The eastern part of the Roman Empire after the division of Roman Empire in 395 AD becomes the eastern Roman Empire. The eastern Roman Empire was later known as Byzantine empire since later European historians wanted to separate the eastern Roman Empire from the Holy Roman Empire thus named the ERE as the Byzantine empire. However people of ERE never referred their country as Byzantine empire.

No. The eastern part of the Roman Empire remained the Roman Empire until it ceased to exist. European “historians" started calling it by that name about a century later so that they could claim Rome for themselves, like thieves who rob the grave of a person to steal their identity.

The eastern Roman Empire saw itself as the legitimate Roman Empire until it fell to the Turks in 1453. Later historians referred to the eastern part of the Roman Empire as Byzantium to differentiate it from the western Roman Empire that fell in 476. The word Byzantium comes from Byzantion which was the original Greek colony dated around 657 BC located in present day Istanbul.
